intro: Adenophora smithii f. crispa, commonly known as the crinkled bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, pale blue to lavender flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or open habitats, often at high elevations. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a crinkled or wavy texture, giving it its cultivar name "crispa." It is valued in horticulture for its ornamental flowers and adaptability to well-drained soils.
